document.title: Curriculum Framework Cambridge Lower Secondary Science 0893

BE58CB1E1E1C4E7A88D10C84E699B69D.description: Discuss how the uses of science can have a global environmental impact.

C24E3A25B81E47F891462E8740FD29B8.description:
Describe how people develop and use scientific understanding as individuals and
through collaboration, e.g. through peer-review.

2A27B377421048BEBD64BE3D89FE690A.description: Evaluate issues which involve and/or require scientific understanding.

5B95988F229D4610B59F17365FF503B9.description: Describe how science is applied across societies and industries, and in research.

0A24A2BE78444AB3B2533CC5E6DAA4C9.description:
Discuss how scientific knowledge is developed through collective understanding and
scrutiny over time.

29F8F9C685C94885BD37278585F85A8C.description:
Describe asteroids as rocks, smaller than planets, and describe their formation from
rocks left over from the formation of a planetary system.

2D8B598DF04D49439437A2FDADCEFEB1.description: Describe a galaxy in terms of stellar dust and gas, stars and planetary systems.

013194C4B008491EA9261FABA11D86B8.description: Describe the difference between climate and weather.

7A9B0813A9184440879813CA7B05EFD7.description: Understand that the Earth's climate can change due to atmospheric change.

D4B0E18AE141463E9D7BEDD4F204C319.description:
Understand that there is evidence that the Earth's climate exists in a cycle between
warm periods and ice ages, and the cycle takes place over long time periods.

399E28AB72594130A79778CB5A778FF5.description:
Identify renewable resources (including wind, tidal and solar power, and bioplastics)
and non-renewable resources (including fossil fuels), and describe how humans use them.

A68F9C93E7294857A64EB9B1920460B7.description:
Know that the reason the Earth has a magnetic field is that the core acts as a
magnet.

98DFD189FDCE4DBBB697A5910A2F7760.description: Investigate factors that change the strength of an electromagnet.

085C92DA2B9F4E2784791F24FFC74EA5.description:
Describe how to make an electromagnet and know that electromagnets have many
applications.

848430ABBBFC4726867FC116099BF9F9.description:
Describe a magnetic field, and understand that it surrounds a magnet and exerts a
force on other magnetic fields.

E8562B9414EE4F4C9C200D1487EE9583.description: Describe how colours of light can be added, subtracted, absorbed and reflected.

88CC0899430D4AA8A419F79BC5338559.description:
Know that white light is made of many colours and this can be shown through the
dispersion of white light, using a prism.

ACEA19CE085644AE902CFFC0773DF0D7.description:
Describe refraction of light at the boundary between air and glass or air and water in
terms of change of speed.

166EE335E7CB4C05986BED18F2A47EC7.description: Describe reflection at a plane surface and use the law of reflection.

7EED732FA6C84DB5885A3BAA9572AC5D.description:
Describe the diffusion of gases and liquids as the intermingling of substances by the
movement of particles.

0C865C83B4114578B21C15A2E0A5978E.description: Use particle theory to explain pressures in gases and liquids (qualitative only).

1C7BA853985045A6B637D06FE5789231.description:
Explain that pressure is caused by the action of a force, exerted by a substance, on
an area (pressure = force / area).

5C73E54AEBF340CC9155EB7BEC2056A4.description: Identify and calculate turning forces (moment = force x distance).

FBD355A31A724935A732ABBE6B63EB9F.description: Describe the effects of balanced and unbalanced forces on motion.

449EC80786B94B8384D2C3049AD995FD.description: Interpret and draw simple distance / time graphs.

1650ADAF503B4F439FD7A64F26B18F4D.description:
Understand that some substances are generally unreactive and can be described as
inert.

00071A7E0A8F430FABCA54CBEB1FA22E.description: Describe how the solubility of different salts varies with temperature.

84DBE0870668404A9CD11968AB0D9248.description:
Know that reactions do not always lead to a single pure product and that sometimes a
reaction will produce an impure mixture of products.

135196D1CB19448094B7F2026A659D2E.description:
Describe the reactivity of metals (limited to sodium, potassium, calcium, magnesium,
zinc, iron, copper, gold and silver) with oxygen, water and dilute acids.

A25C5A96CA9549F2966025EBEE60BDAD.description:
Know that some processes and reactions are endothermic or exothermic, and this
can be identified by temperature change.

1B80E35DEC6D491183AB9DE8A8FBA793.description: Use word equations to describe reactions.

89913D3B81A5433FA441A13C0FD01677.description:
Describe how paper chromatography can be used to separate and identify
substances in a sample.

3A88D70051FA4929B7C76CE33657BB9D.description:
Understand that the concentration of a solution relates to how many particles of the
solute are present in a volume of the solvent.

7A1D285F7BAB425ABFCE68B972AFE47F.description: Know that purity is a way to describe how much of a specific chemical is in a mixture.

C90DFF9A645E43999D979F1DE529CD5F.description:
Know that the electrostatic attraction between positive and negative charge is what
holds together individual atoms.

01557966955C491EB00ADF3D37033573.description:
Know that electrons have negative charge, protons have positive charge and
neutrons have no charge.

648004DF6F374F289AEF80B0E6CD992E.description: Describe the Rutherford model of the structure of an atom.

A151106C209E4772A8DBD10ADDCEF718.description:
Describe how a new and/or invasive species can affect other organisms and an
ecosystem.

DCF38E40612A4FB8AC91BFA25ED18EAA.description: Describe the impact of the bioaccumulation of toxic substances on an ecosystem.

1C76491145C543E7AB9D0A2BB2759756.description:
Identify different ecosystems on the Earth, recognising the variety of habitats that
exist within an ecosystem.

AA322F40613C4D2297453945F411881C.description:
Know and use the summary word equation for aerobic respiration
(glucose + oxygen  carbon dioxide + water).

224D93842EFB429BA17BAE894FEA09A8.description:
Know that aerobic respiration occurs in the mitochondria of plant and animal cells,
and gives a controlled release of energy.

2E177F7E4D9A4BDABD8C89510D112D96.description:
Discuss how human growth, development and health can be affected by lifestyle,
including diet and smoking.

DF9A7F82C6B54192BE69D1D3D0246A21.description:
Understand that carbohydrates and fats can be used as a store of energy in animals,
and animals consume food to obtain energy and nutrients.

50F4A8B2B3004DA4B35348DFAD238E9E.description:
Identify the constituents of a balanced diet for humans as including protein,
carbohydrates, fats and oils, water, minerals (limited to calcium and iron) and vitamins
(limited to A, C and D), and describe the functions of these nutrients.

619E6D5777F94E3EA4E144ACE04443EA.description:
Describe the diffusion of oxygen and carbon dioxide between blood and the air in the
lungs.

C8081B5F90CB4028A102130A59F48ADF.description:
Describe how the structure of the human respiratory system is related to its function
of gas exchange (in terms of lung structure and the action of the diaphragm and intercostal
muscles) and understand the difference between breathing and respiration.

736EB46580C44058A53BB3B87AD263E0.description:
Describe the components of blood and their functions (limited to red blood cells
transporting oxygen, white blood cells protecting against pathogens and plasma transporting
blood cells, nutrients and carbon dioxide).

C621A88EE7F74834A759FCB4F1D1278C.description:
Identify ball-and-socket and hinge joints, and explain how antagonistic muscles move
the bones at a hinge joint.

8E180044A26D48EC821F209E79D80732.description: Present and interpret observations and measurements appropriately.

7DBA269C142E452B8FD7AB871C26456D.description:
Evaluate experiments and investigations, and suggest improvements, explaining
any proposed changes.

2D1646474E1A45E6BD84ABB03B002D81.description:
Make conclusions by interpreting results and explain the limitations of the
conclusions.

03D6EE9F95C34397B168B6FA6C2E0FF5.description:
Describe trends and patterns in results, including identifying any anomalous
results.

0E5BC328DAC54AF7B632A7D6F58343CA.description:
Describe the accuracy of predictions, based on results, and suggest why they
were or were not accurate.

673E14B69F61402591634826CA688276.description: Scientific enquiry: analysis, evaluation and conclusions

2A7992A4B0E04B2A95F25FD137B5F1A1.description:
Collect and record sufficient observations and/or measurements in an appropriate
form.

6B8E0B76C76745F998C6DCB7383C604E.description:
Evaluate a range of secondary information sources for their relevance and know
that some sources may be biased.

DC6A845919884F0FA317C7C67D8F62CF.description: Carry out practical work safely, supported by risk assessments where appropriate.

F2138AC3465E4F7C984D684CA4376584.description:
Take appropriately accurate and precise measurements, explaining why accuracy
and precision are important.

AC79C86585004F7085F360A78D799D84.description:
Evaluate whether measurements and observations have been repeated
sufficiently to be reliable.

307DDBB76E3A4585B43F356D962C791C.description:
Decide what equipment is required to carry out an investigation or experiment and
use it appropriately.

DA262D42A72745ECB715A1C5542DE929.description:
Sort, group and classify phenomena, objects, materials and organisms through
testing, observation, using secondary information, and making and using keys.

812300E26722468EAD1F2665E645DB60.description: Make risk assessments for practical work to identify and control risks.

AF558C5BB7AC421C90DA401E60B11D17.description:
Plan a range of investigations of different types, while considering variables
appropriately, and recognise that not all investigations can be fair tests.

258DC8C29CDC48A1B7A933090F6F0E65.description:
Make predictions of likely outcomes for a scientific enquiry based on scientific
knowledge and understanding.

9D7D1A70C9C14E97A9F87CD7EEE29C50.description:
Describe how scientific hypotheses can be supported or contradicted by evidence
from an enquiry.

64A625DAB0C14246BF83B474DBEB2340.description: Identify whether a given hypothesis is testable.

08686EA9047040A5BD1BF85B4B6B756B.description: Use symbols and formulae to represent scientific ideas.

EB790F2A20504E3C9764013E8251ACDC.description: Use an existing analogy for a purpose.

2D5DB9BE7F194817A10632B671658FA6.description: Describe what an analogy is and how it can be used as a model.
